rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
==Notable examples==
==Notable examples==
â
[[Image:Deathofsuperman.jpg|thumb|175px|left|Superman "dies" in [[Lois Lane]]'s arms, in the ''[[Death of Superman]]'' storyline.]]
 
At least three comic book deaths are well known. The first two are the 1980 "death" of [[Jean Grey]] in Marvel's ''[[Dark Phoenix Saga]]'' and that of [[Superman]] in [[DC Comics|DC]]'s highly-publicized 1993 ''[[Death of Superman]]'' storyline. There is one major distinction between the two, however - whereas it was never intended that Superman's death be permanent, and that he would return to life at the conclusion of the story{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}, Jean's passing (one of many temporary deaths among the [[X-Men]]) was written as the true and permanent death of the character,{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} only to be [[retcon]]ned a few years later to facilitate her return. In more recent history, the death of [[Captain America]] made real-world headlines in early 2007<ref>[http://www.opinionjournal.com/la/?id=110009780 Captain America, RIP], para. 5, ''Wall Street Journal'', March 13, 2007</ref> when he met his apparent end, but Steve Rogers returned in ''[[Captain America: Reborn]]'' in late 2009.
At least three comic book deaths are well known. The first two are the 1980 "death" of [[Jean Grey]] in Marvel's ''[[Dark Phoenix Saga]]'' and that of [[Superman]] in [[DC Comics|DC]]'s highly-publicized 1993 ''[[Death of Superman]]'' storyline. There is one major distinction between the two, however - whereas it was never intended that Superman's death be permanent, and that he would return to life at the conclusion of the story{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}, Jean's passing (one of many temporary deaths among the [[X-Men]]) was written as the true and permanent death of the character,{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} only to be [[retcon]]ned a few years later to facilitate her return. In more recent history, the death of [[Captain America]] made real-world headlines in early 2007<ref>[http://www.opinionjournal.com/la/?id=110009780 Captain America, RIP], para. 5, ''Wall Street Journal'', March 13, 2007</ref> when he met his apparent end, but Steve Rogers returned in ''[[Captain America: Reborn]]'' in late 2009.
